required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of a Musical Intervention on Stress Response to Venepuncture
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of a Musical Intervention on Stress Response to Venepuncture

brief_summary.textblock: Randomised Crossover Trial in Preterm Infants less than 32 weeks to assess Music therapy and sucrose versus sucrose on stress

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to assess whether the use of music therapy as a non-pharmacological intervention around the time of venepuncture significantly decreases the stress response of a stable preterm neonate, as measured by salivary cortisol levels .
The secondary aim of this study is to analyse the effect of music therapy on the EEG, and vital signs of the stable preterm neonate.

primary_outcome.description: Change in salivary cortisol levels between Baseline, 20 minutes and 4 hours

secondary_outcome.description: Alteration in pain as measured by Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) score

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in physiological parameters - Heart rate
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 10 mins before venepuncture and 10 mins after

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in physiological parameters - respiration rate
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 10 mins before venepuncture and 10 mins after

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in physiological parameters - oxygen saturation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 10 mins before venepuncture and 10 mins after
10 mins before venepuncture and 10 mins after

arm_group.description: These infants will receive an oral sucrose solution ("Sweetease") only prior to venepuncture
These infants will receive both oral sucrose solution and music therapy prior to venepuncture.

intervention.description: The musical intervention will be played for ten minutes prior to venepuncture

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Infants born at less than 32 weeks gestational age (from 23+0 weeks' up to and including 31+6 weeks' gestational age)
- Infants must now be >32 weeks corrected gestational age
- Infants who are medically stable and due to have routine venepuncture as part of their management plan
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to obtain informed consent from parent
- Infants with known hearing impairment
- Infants receiving sedative medications
- Any evidence of dysfunction of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis
- Infants with congenital abnormalities
- Infants with known EEG abnormalities
